EVENT_NARRATIVE: A meteorologist with Florida Power and Light reported downed trees, large branches, wooden power poles, and powerlines after a severe thunderstorm moved through the Redland area. Estimated wind gusts of up to 60 mph / 52 kt occurred based on the wind damage, nearby observations, and radar velocity data.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak mid-level low was centered over the Florida Peninsula, with dry air aloft due to a Saharan Air Layer. Low-level southeast winds brought in sufficient moisture, which combined with steep mid-level lapse rates to support isolated strong to severe thunderstorms over portions of South Florida on the afternoon and evening of July 10th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Southwest flow produced a stronger west coast sea breeze that converged with the east coast sea breeze toward the I-95 corridor during the late afternoon and evening. Resultant strong storms with wind gust of 40-50 mph moved offshore of the coast into the evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prevailing SW flow combined with the river, lake and sea breezes converged east of Highway 301 in the late evening over a moist and unstable airmass. Numerous boundary mergers produced waterspouts over the St. Johns River west of Hastings, FL and over Lake George. The waterspout over Lake George shifted onto Drayton Island and became a landspout. No damages or injuries were reported. Other storms produced gusty winds and locally heavy rainfall especially across SE GA, including some localized flooding reports.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 3:30 pm EDT on July 21, 2024, an employee working as a roofer for a roofing contractor was installing a single ply roof over an existing metal roof when a storm approached. As the crew was covering up their tools, the employee was struck by lightning. The employee died from multiple injuries due to the lightning strike.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours in a typical summertime environment.  A few storms produced gusty winds with isolated impacts.  In addition, there was one fatality due to a lightning strike in Gadsden county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A remote NWS storm survey in consultation with the Village of Islamorada Emergency Manager and several residents, social media videos and photos, as well as in-situ review of realtime Florida Department of Transportation video revealed a wet microburst occurred in the upper Plantation Key area of the Indian Mounds Trail neighborhood.  Estimated wind gusts of 60 to 85 mph occurred over an area about one to one and a half miles wide by two miles long as the microburst began on the oceanside of the Old Overseas Highway.  The straight-line winds associated with the microburst crossed U.S. Highway 1 into the Indian Mounds Trail Neighborhood.  Numerous large trees and tree tops were downed in an area over 5 blocks long, with secondary damages to several vehicles and a broken window of one residence.  Lighter but sizable yard objects including furniture, trash receptacles were tossed one or more lots downwind, with one trampoline lofted into a tree.  Several of the neighborhood streets were temporarily impassible due to the size of the tree limbs.  Some minor fascia and shingle damage was also noted at a few residences.  Approximately 1,100 residents were without power as the tree limbs downed utility lines, with one tree partially blocking northbound U.S. Highway 1.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wet microburst occurred in association with a strong thunderstorm moving north around 25 mph over the upper portion of Plantation Key. A small-scale elongated swath of wind damage to trees and lose, small to medium-sized yard objects occurred. Power outages, secondary damages to parked vehicles due to falling large tree limbs occurred with estimated straight-line wind gusts between 60 and 85 mph.  Post-analysis indicated a pronounced layer of dry mid-level air with both convective instability and downburst potential well above climatological normal for July.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: County dispatch relayed report of 4 individuals that were struck by lightning and injured while standing under a tree near downtown St. Petersburg around 5:45 pm local time. Ensuing reports detailed that all 4 individuals were teenagers, 2 females and 1 male aged 16 along with a 17 year old male, and that one of the 16 year old girls had gone into cardiac arrest. Paramedics arriving on scene were able to restore the girl's pulse before taking her to Orlando Health Bayfront Hospital in St. Petersburg, along with one of the males that had received burns, and all 4 of the individuals were ultimately taken to Johns Hopkins All Children's Hospital for treatment and monitoring. Unfortunately, the 16 year old girl that had to be resuscitated on scene later succumbed to her injuries on August 19.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lightning from afternoon thunderstorms associated with the sea breeze causes 1 fatality and 3 injuries near St Petersburg in Pinellas County, and a structure fire near Palmetto in Manatee County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High moisture levels on the far northern end of a tropical disturbance (future Hurricane Debby) over eastern Cuba led to the development of afternoon thunderstorms over interior sections of South Florida.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tropical storm force wind gusts in the range of 55 to 63 mph were observed by several sites in the Lower Florida Keys of Monroe County as the result of the passage of strong rain bands from Tropical Storm Debby.  Brief power outages affecting less than 50 customers at a time were reported in the Key West area, with scattered tree limbs and one tree downed.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The center of Tropical Storm Debby, before attaining hurricane strength, passed about 85 nautical miles to the west-southwest of Key West on a north-northwest path|through the southeastern Gulf of Mexico. Tropical storm-force wind gusts occurred in rain bands extending throughout the Straits of Florida and Florida Keys. Sustained tropical storm force winds occurred over the coastal waters mainly from along the Lower Florida Keys west of the Seven Mile Bridge through Dry Tortugas. The tropical-storm force wind gusts resulted in fallen large tree limbs and isolated power outages primarily affecting a street block or a multi-unit residential complex at a time. The combination high tide and strong southerly winds sustained just below tropical storm force resulted in storm tides up to an estimated 1.8 feet above MHHW|along the oceanside of the Lower Florida Keys, but lower water levels were measured at gauges in the lee along the Gulf of Mexico and Florida Bay side of the Florida Keys. Moderate to heavy ocean wave overwash resulted in temporary flooding on oceanfront low elevation streets in Key West. In combination with brief heavy rainfall from the rain bands, a section of State Road A1A in Key West was closed due to having litte or no drainage in a construction zone.
Thunderstorms developed across portions of the area and produced strong wind gusts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm force wind gusts of 45 to 50 mph were observed at several sites in the Middle Florida Keys of Monroe County, mainly from the passage of strong rain bands from Tropical Storm Debby. Brief power outages affecting less than 50 customers at a time were reported in the Marathon vicinity due to tree limbs contacting power lines.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The center of Tropical Storm Debby, before attaining hurricane strength, passed about 85 nautical miles to the west-southwest of Key West on a north-northwest path|through the southeastern Gulf of Mexico. Tropical storm-force wind gusts occurred in rain bands extending throughout the Straits of Florida and Florida Keys. Sustained tropical storm force winds occurred over the coastal waters mainly from along the Lower Florida Keys west of the Seven Mile Bridge through Dry Tortugas. The tropical-storm force wind gusts resulted in fallen large tree limbs and isolated power outages primarily affecting a street block or a multi-unit residential complex at a time. The combination high tide and strong southerly winds sustained just below tropical storm force resulted in storm tides up to an estimated 1.8 feet above MHHW|along the oceanside of the Lower Florida Keys, but lower water levels were measured at gauges in the lee along the Gulf of Mexico and Florida Bay side of the Florida Keys. Moderate to heavy ocean wave overwash resulted in temporary flooding on oceanfront low elevation streets in Key West. In combination with brief heavy rainfall from the rain bands, a section of State Road A1A in Key West was closed due to having litte or no drainage in a construction zone.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Maximum sustained winds were in the 30 to 35 mph range across coastal Broward County. Brief wind gusts of tropical storm force occurred mainly on August 3rd. Highest wind gust of 67 mph was recorded at Pompano Beach High School at 9:47 PM on August 3rd. There was minor wind damage, mainly to trees, across parts of the area.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The center of Debby passed about 140 miles west of Naples as a tropical storm moving north-northwest over the eastern Gulf of Mexico around 8 AM EDT on August 4th. Tropical Storm Debby intensified into a hurricane as it passed southwest of Tampa late August 4th before making landfall in the Florida Big Bend area as a Category 1 hurricane on the morning of August 5th, with maximum sustained winds of 80 mph and lowest central pressure of 979 mb. The outermost edge of Debby's tropical storm force wind field skirted the southwestern Florida Gulf coast on August 3rd and 4th. bringing brief tropical storm force wind gusts to most of the area. The most persistent rain bands moved over western, southern, and central sections of Collier County on August 4th, producing near-tropical storm conditions and rainfall of 4-6 inches. A storm surge of just over 3 feet, in combination with the high rainfall amounts, led to moderate coastal flooding in vulnerable storm surge locations in coastal Collier County during the high tide cycle on August 4th. The heavy rainfall also caused widespread minor to moderate inland flooding across the Naples and Golden Gate areas.||The combination of heavy rainfall and storm surge caused a total of $877,947 in damage in unincorporated sections of Collier County (excluding the cities of Marco Island, Everglades City, and Naples), with 6 properties suffering major damage and 31 with minor damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Maximum sustained winds were in the 25 to 30 mph range across metro Palm Beach County. Brief wind gusts of tropical storm force occurred mainly on August 3rd and 4th. Highest wind gust of 45 mph was recorded at Palm Beach International Airport at 12:29 PM on August 4th. Wind damage was minimal.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Surface observations indicate peak wind gusts generally between 45 to 55 mph, with a maximum gust of 55 mph at Tarpon Point at 5:27 PM EST on August 4. Rainfall ranged from 4 to 8 inches, with a maximum total of 8.11 inches near Fort Myers.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Debby made landfall north of the local area along the Big Bend region of Florida near Steinhatchee around 7 AM EST on August 5th as a Category 1 hurricane with maximum sustained winds of 80 mph and a minimum pressure of 979 mb. Despite Debbys track west of the Florida peninsula, impacts overspread the area from coastal locations spreading inland.|Storm surge affected the immediate coast from Ft. Myers northward through Cedar Key, where water levels peaked over 4 feet above normally dry ground across the upper Nature Coast and the Cedar Key area. Wind gusts of up to 60 to 70 mph affected much of the western Florida coast, with the strongest winds occurring along immediate coastal areas from around Tampa and St. Petersburg northward across Nature Coast locations, producing generally minor damage along with power outages. Torrential rainfall accompanied Debby as the rainbands east of its center moved across the area. Totals as high as 15 to 20 inches were reported, with hardest hit west-central and southwest Florida areas requiring numerous water rescues from flooded vehicles and homes as a result of extensive flash flooding and subsequent river flooding, and at least one official river gauge site established a new record crest. Multiple supercells embedded within outer rain bands east of Debbys center produced at least 3 tornadoes across the area, however, associated damage remained relatively minor. |Debbys overall impacts across the western Florida peninsula resulted in 2 direct fatalities and 3 indirect fatalities, with numerous homes and additional businesses receiving damage from freshwater flash and river flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Surface observations indicate peak wind gusts generally between 45 to 55 mph, with a maximum gust of 55 mph at Tarpon Point at 5:27 PM EST on August 4. Rainfall ranged from 4 to 8 inches, with a maximum total of 8.11 inches near Fort Myers. A peak water level of 3.27 feet above MHHW was measured at Fort Myers at 3:30 PM EST on August 4. Peak water levels estimated elsewhere along coastal Lee County generally ranged from 2 to 4 feet above MHHW.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Debby made landfall north of the local area along the Big Bend region of Florida near Steinhatchee around 7 AM EST on August 5th as a Category 1 hurricane with maximum sustained winds of 80 mph and a minimum pressure of 979 mb. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm tides of 1.0 to 1.5 feet above mean higher high water were observed along the south shores of Key West, causing temporary flooding and the closure of State Road A1A in Key West.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The center of Tropical Storm Debby, before attaining hurricane strength, passed about 85 nautical miles to the west-southwest of Key West on a north-northwest path|through the southeastern Gulf of Mexico. Tropical storm-force wind gusts occurred in rain bands extending throughout the Straits of Florida and Florida Keys. Sustained tropical storm force winds occurred over the coastal waters mainly from along the Lower Florida Keys west of the Seven Mile Bridge through Dry Tortugas. Moderate to heavy ocean wave overwash resulted in temporary flooding on oceanfront low elevation streets in Key West. In combination with brief heavy rainfall from the rain bands, a section of State Road A1A in Key West was closed due to having litte or no drainage in a construction zone.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Surface observations indicate peak wind gusts generally between 55 to 65 mph, with a maximum gust of 64 mph at Sarasota-Bradenton International Airport at 9:30 PM EST on August 4. Rainfall ranged from 10 to 20 inches, with a maximum total of 18.86 inches near Parrish. As a result of the rainfall, the Manatee River at Rye Bridge reached a record crest of 20.12 feet on August 5 at 8:15 PM EST, surpassing the previous record of 20 feet set on July 21, 1962. Over 200 people were high-water rescued as a result of the flooding across the Parrish and eastern Manatee County communities. A peak water level of 2.42 feet above MHHW was measured at Port Manatee at 2:48 AM EST on August 5. Peak water levels estimated elsewhere along coastal Manatee County generally ranged from 2 to 3 feet above MHHW.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Debby made landfall north of the local area along the Big Bend region of Florida near Steinhatchee around 7 AM EST on August 5th as a Category 1 hurricane with maximum sustained winds of 80 mph and a minimum pressure of 979 mb. Despite Debbys track west of the Florida peninsula, impacts overspread the area from coastal locations spreading inland.|Storm surge affected the immediate coast from Ft. Myers northward through Cedar Key, where water levels peaked over 4 feet above normally dry ground across the upper Nature Coast and the Cedar Key area. Wind gusts of up to 60 to 70 mph affected much of the western Florida coast, with the strongest winds occurring along immediate coastal areas from around Tampa and St. Petersburg northward across Nature Coast locations, producing generally minor damage along with power outages. Torrential rainfall accompanied Debby as the rainbands east of its center moved across the area. Totals as high as 15 to 20 inches were reported, with hardest hit west-central and southwest Florida areas requiring numerous water rescues from flooded vehicles and homes as a result of extensive flash flooding and subsequent river flooding, and at least one official river gauge site established a new record crest. Multiple supercells embedded within outer rain bands east of Debbys center produced at least 3 tornadoes across the area, however, associated damage remained relatively minor. |Debbys overall impacts across the western Florida peninsula resulted in 2 direct fatalities and 3 indirect fatalities, with numerous homes and additional businesses receiving damage from freshwater flash and river flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Surface observations indicate peak wind gusts generally between 50 to 60 mph, with a maximum gust of 54 mph near North Sarasota at 6:20 PM EST, and Venice at 8 PM EST, each on August 4. Rainfall ranged from 10 to 20 inches, with a maximum total of 17.78 inches near Sarasota. As a result of the rainfall, the Myakka River at Myakka River State Park reached a crest of 10.22 feet on August 9 at 6:00 AM EST, which is the 10th highest crest on record. Over 500 people were high-water rescued as a result of the flooding across the Pinecraft and Phillippi Creek neighborhoods, and areas along the Myakka River. A peak water level of 3.81 feet above MHHW was measured at North Port at 5:00 PM EST on August 4. Peak water levels measured elsewhere along coastal Sarasota County generally ranged from 2 to 4 feet above MHHW. A direct fatality occurred when a 67 year old male drove through the flood waters near Phillippi Creek and his vehicle was swept away and he drowned.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Debby made landfall north of the local area along the Big Bend region of Florida near Steinhatchee around 7 AM EST on August 5th as a Category 1 hurricane with maximum sustained winds of 80 mph and a minimum pressure of 979 mb. Despite Debbys track west of the Florida peninsula, impacts overspread the area from coastal locations spreading inland.|Storm surge affected the immediate coast from Ft. Myers northward through Cedar Key, where water levels peaked over 4 feet above normally dry ground across the upper Nature Coast and the Cedar Key area. Wind gusts of up to 60 to 70 mph affected much of the western Florida coast, with the strongest winds occurring along immediate coastal areas from around Tampa and St. Petersburg northward across Nature Coast locations, producing generally minor damage along with power outages. Torrential rainfall accompanied Debby as the rainbands east of its center moved across the area. Totals as high as 15 to 20 inches were reported, with hardest hit west-central and southwest Florida areas requiring numerous water rescues from flooded vehicles and homes as a result of extensive flash flooding and subsequent river flooding, and at least one official river gauge site established a new record crest. Multiple supercells embedded within outer rain bands east of Debbys center produced at least 3 tornadoes across the area, however, associated damage remained relatively minor. |Debbys overall impacts across the western Florida peninsula resulted in 2 direct fatalities and 3 indirect fatalities, with numerous homes and additional businesses receiving damage from freshwater flash and river flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor coastal flooding was observed in Flamingo during high tide on the afternoon of August 4th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The center of Debby passed about 140 miles west of Naples as a tropical storm moving north-northwest over the eastern Gulf of Mexico around 8 AM EDT on August 4th. Tropical Storm Debby intensified into a hurricane as it passed southwest of Tampa late August 4th before making landfall in the Florida Big Bend area as a Category 1 hurricane on the morning of August 5th, with maximum sustained winds of 80 mph and lowest central pressure of 979 mb. The outermost edge of Debby's tropical storm force wind field skirted the southwestern Florida Gulf coast on August 3rd and 4th. bringing brief tropical storm force wind gusts to most of the area. The most persistent rain bands moved over western, southern, and central sections of Collier County on August 4th, producing near-tropical storm conditions and rainfall of 4-6 inches. A storm surge of just over 3 feet, in combination with the high rainfall amounts, led to moderate coastal flooding in vulnerable storm surge locations in coastal Collier County during the high tide cycle on August 4th. The heavy rainfall also caused widespread minor to moderate inland flooding across the Naples and Golden Gate areas.||The combination of heavy rainfall and storm surge caused a total of $877,947 in damage in unincorporated sections of Collier County (excluding the cities of Marco Island, Everglades City, and Naples), with 6 properties suffering major damage and 31 with minor damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A maximum storm tide of 3.11 ft above Mean Higher High Water (MHHW) was measured by the NOAA/NOS gauge at Naples Pier at 2:06 PM on August 4th. This resulted in street flooding and closure of numerous near-coastal areas in Collier County during the high tide cycles of August 4th and 5th. There were several reports of roads underwater and water entering homes in Naples, Pelican Bay, Everglades City, and Vanderbilt Beach during the August 4th peak high tide between 10AM to 4PM. It was likely a combination of storm surge, high tide, and heavy rainfall. Water depth was approximately 1-2 feet on many streets in the Naples and Golden Gate areas, and 4 to 6 inches that fell during high tide also contributed to the amount and extent of the flooding. ||In Everglades City and Chokoloskee, generally 1 to 1.5 feet of inundation was indicated by the storm survey, with a maximum high water mark of 27 inches at the Smallwood Store in Chokoloskee.||Total damage in unincorporated sections of Collier County (excluding the cities of Marco Island, Everglades City, and Naples) was $877,947, with 6 properties suffering major damage and 31 with minor damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Suwannee was the most heavily impacted county in the NWS Jacksonville area as the eyewall of Debby crossed over the county through the day on 8/5. Widespread flash flooding occurred with water inundation into structures and swift water rescue deployments. Most of the City of Live Oak was flooded and the southern end of the county was inaccessible for some time after the storm. Most businesses in the city of|Live Oak were flooded and a major county road was completely washed out near the Community of Wellborn. U.S. Highway 90 was closed for about 36 hours. The Miami-Dade Urban Search and Rescue (USAR) Team was deployed to the southern end of the county with the initial push south and a large Incident Management Team (IMT) effort was set up in Live Oak. Extensive tree and structure damage was observed county-wide. Major main stem river flooding was occurring on both the Suwannee and Santa Fe Rivers. On 8/5 at 3:40 am local time, a wind gust of 40 mph was measured in Dowling Park and at 4:40 am the gusts were 41 mph. By 5:10 am, the gusts strengthened to 48 mph then 49 mph at 6 am. At 6:15 am on 8/5, the Suwannee Airport AWOS gust to 46 mph and at 6:20 am the mesonet in Dowling Park measured a gust of 53 mph. On 8/5 at 12:20 PM, a peak wind gust of 65 mph was observed at FAWN Suwannee Advent Christian Village WeatherSTEM site.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Debby made landfall as a Category 1 storm along the FL Big Bend coast during the early morning of August 5, 2024. Prior to landfall, outer convective bands produced tornadoes across portions of northeast Florida on August 4th. Widespread flooding moved inland with Debby across the Suwannee River Valley and inland Southeast Georgia where flash flooding and moderate to major river flooding occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Keystone Heights Airport AWOS measured gusts between 40-52 mph during Debby. 6.22 inches of rainfall was measured by a COOP observer at 2.0 NE New River during Debby. The peak gust of 52 mph was measured at 3:35 am on 8/5 local time.

Prior to landfall, outer convective bands produced tornadoes across portions of northeast Florida on August 4th. Widespread flooding moved inland with Debby across the Suwannee River Valley and inland Southeast Georgia where flash flooding and moderate to major river flooding occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread downed trees and powerlines were reported across the county. A tree fell on a home and caused unknown damage. A road was reported to be washed out. 4.56 inches of rainfall was measured by a CoCoRaHS observer in Hollister during Debby. The AWOS site at Palatka Airport (K28J) measured a peak wind gust of 47 mph on 8/5 at 12:35 PM.

Prior to landfall, outer convective bands produced tornadoes across portions of northeast Florida on August 4th. Widespread flooding moved inland with Debby across the Suwannee River Valley and inland Southeast Georgia where flash flooding and moderate to major river flooding occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tropical cyclone wind gusts impacted the county on 8/5. Wind gusts between 40-54 mph were observed during Debby. At 5:58 pm on 8/4, the mesonet at Marineland measured a wind gust of 54 mph. At 6:20 am on 8/5, the station measured 41 mph wind gusts. Flagler county EMA reported a few trees were downed in Palm Coast and Bunnell.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts between 50-58 mph were observed during Debby and 7.28 inches of rainfall was measured by a CoCoRaHS observer at Sawgrass 0.0 E during Debby. On 8/4 at 9:10 pm local time, the mesonet station in downtown St. Augustine measured a wind gust of 44 mph in an outer rainband.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Debby made landfall as a Category 1 storm along the FL Big Bend coast during the early morning of August 5, 2024. Prior to landfall, outer convective bands produced tornadoes across portions of northeast Florida on August 4th. Widespread flooding moved inland with Debby across the Suwannee River Valley and inland Southeast Georgia where flash flooding and moderate to major river flooding occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Most of the county's impacts included wind damage and flooding. On 8/5, State Warning Point relayed that the City of Lake Butler reported an ongoing raw sewage release of approximately 3,000-4,000 gallons from the wastewater treatment plant due to a lightning strike on the generator. No storm drains or waterways were impacted. SW CR-231A in Lake Butler was closed due to large fallen trees along the road. 7.22 inches of rainfall was measured by a COOP observer at 3.6 NW Lake Butler during Debby. The EM reported that the WeatherStem station at the county courthouse in Lake Butler measured 9.99 inches of storm total rainfall and had a peak wind gust of 45 mph during Debby. On 8/4 at 7:40 PM, one of Debbys rainbands produced a severe tornadic thunderstorm. The tornado was rated an EF1 and touched down about a quarter of a mile south of State Road 238 and about a quarter mile east of Southwest County Road 241 and moved northwest towards Southwest 85th Path. The tornado produced EF1 tornado damage at 7:40 PM as it touched down south of State Road 238 by snapping the tree trunk of a large hardwood tree. The tornado proceeded northwest to homes along Southwest 85th Path, overturning a travel trailer, knocking down a wooden fence, and uprooting another hardwood tree. The tornado's last impact was tearing off the roof of a shed along Southwest 85th Path before it lifted. The tornado was on the ground for about 1 minute and was on the ground a distance of just under a quarter of a mile. The tornado had a maximum width of about 20 yards and had maximum winds up to about 93 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Debby made landfall as a Category 1 storm along the FL Big Bend coast during the early morning of August 5, 2024. Prior to landfall, outer convective bands produced tornadoes across portions of northeast Florida on August 4th. Widespread flooding moved inland with Debby across the Suwannee River Valley and inland Southeast Georgia where flash flooding and moderate to major river flooding occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple road closures were reported due to downed trees and powerlines across roadways.  Measured gusts ranged from 40-54 mph between 2 am on 8/5 through 7 am on 8/5. Wind damage started to impact the county during the evening of 8/4. At 8 pm local time, a tree was blown down near NW 43rd Street in Gainesville. By 9:13 pm local time, all lines of State Road 24 in Gainesville had to be closed due to a downed tree. Fallen trees were also reported blocking all lanes along SR-222. Fallen trees and downed power lines were also reported across the University of Florida campus. In Gainesville and Alachua, a number of homes suffered minor to major damage due to flooding, and several trees fell onto homes. On 8/5 at 8:11 am EDT, State Warning Point relayed a report that there was damage to a residence in Alachua due to a tree of unknown size that destroyed the home, but with no injuries.  About 8.75 inches of rainfall was measured by a CoCoRaHS observer at Brooker 1.6 SW during Debby. On the University of Florida campus, the EM relayed that there were several trees blown down, minor roadway flooding at times and water flooded into a few buildings. The WeatherStem on campus measured 7.19 inches of storm total rainfall and the highest wind gust was 54 mph during the early morning hours of 8/5. At the Santa Fe Community College in Gainesville, the EM reported significant water damage was reported at several campus buildings and downed tree limbs and wires were blown down.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Debby made landfall as a Category 1 storm along the FL Big Bend coast during the early morning of August 5, 2024. Prior to landfall, outer convective bands produced tornadoes across portions of northeast Florida on August 4th. Widespread flooding moved inland with Debby across the Suwannee River Valley and inland Southeast Georgia where flash flooding and moderate to major river flooding occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: AWOS station KOCF Ocala Airport gusted to 41 mph during Debby on 8/5 at 1:14 am local time. A CoCoRaHS observer measured 9.37 inches of rainfall at Micanopy 3.6 SSW during Debby.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several inches of water was reported across Southern States Nursery Rd in Macclenny. The St. Marys River near Macclenny reached major flood stage and peaked at 19.71 ft on Aug. 7th. 9.67 inches of rainfall was measured by a CoCoRaHS observer at Glen St. Mary 4.4 SW during Debby.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: SR-26 was closed at the Gilchrist and Alachua County line due to flooding. SR-47 from NE CR-340 to SE CR-232 was closed in Gilchrist County due to downed trees, powerlines, and flooding. Peak wind gust of 42 mph was measured by 0651W 4.7 W Newberry  WEATHERSTEM) on 8/5 at 5 am local time. 10.32 inches of rainfall was measured by a|CoCoRaHS observer at 5 W Newberry during Debby.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Debby made landfall as a Category 1 storm along the FL Big Bend coast during the early morning of August 5, 2024. Prior to landfall, outer convective bands produced tornadoes across portions of northeast Florida on August 4th. Widespread flooding moved inland with Debby across the Suwannee River Valley and inland Southeast Georgia where flash flooding and moderate to major river flooding occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple downed trees and powerlines were reported blown down across the county. A tree snapped and fell on a car causing damage in Riverside. A large tree uprooted and fell on a house causing roof damage along Ribault Scenic Dr. Edgewood Ave was closed due to flooding. Wind gusts between 40-62 mph were observed during Debby. 6.29 inches of rainfall was measured by a CoCoRaHS observer at Jacksonville 11.3 WNW during Debby.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The county experienced gusts of tropical storm force and flooding rainfall with 11.63 inches of rainfallmeasured by a CoCoRaHS observer at White Springs 0.3 NW during Debby. Wind gusts between 41-44 mph were observed during Debby. At 6:20 am local time on 8/5, a mesonet station 3 miles SSE of Jasper measured wind gusts of 44 mph. At 6:30 am, a mesonet station 6 miles NE of Suwannee Springs measured a wind gust of 41 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nassau County Emergency Management reported that Stokes Road bridge was closed due to being inundated by river flooding on the Georgia side of the St. Marys River. St. Marys river also flooded the Scotts Landing boat ramp and nearby sheds at St. Marys river campground. The St. Marys River near Macclenny reached major flood stage and peaked at 19.71 ft on Aug. 7th. The St. Marys River at Traders Hill reached|major flood stage and peaked at 16.17 ft on Aug. 10th. Zidell Road in Callahan was closed due to deep floodwaters making it impassable. A car was also stranded in the floodwaters. CR-119 and CR-121 were reported flooded but passable. 9.27 inches of rainfall were reported in Hilliard, FL during Debby. The AWOS station KFHB Fernandina Beach gusted to 46 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread impacts due to major flash flooding were reported across Columbia county. 12.55 inches of rainfall was measured by a CoCoRaHS observer at Lake City 7.9 SSW during Debby. Wind gusts between 40-48 mph were observed during Debby.|On 8/4 around 8 PM, Columbia County EM and Storm Spotters reported an observed tornado on the ground off HWY 441 near Lake City Airpark and then it crossed I-75 about 3-4 miles south of Lake City.  Along the Columbia - Suwannee county line (SW Alfalfa Ave), a home suffered complete destruction of their roof, nearby structures/out-buildings collapse and large tree branches snapped off and were tossed across the yard. On 8/5 at 9:52 pm, Columbia county EM reported State Road 240 in Lake City was washed out and would be closed for an|extended period due to flooding. One submerged vehicle was reported. State Road 247 and Peacock Terrace were closed due to flooding. Trees also snapped at the trunk near Alligator Lake.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple road closures were reported due to downed trees and powerlines across roadways. Measured gusts ranged from 40-54 mph between 2 am on 8/5 through 7 am on 8/5. Wind damage started to impact the county during the evening of 8/4.|Around 2 am on 8/5, the EM reported a tree down on the 4900 block of SW SR-45 in the Newberry area which blocked all lanes. The tree caused a traffic crash which resulted in one injury. Fallen trees were also reported blocking all lanes along SR-24, and SR-26 at NW 242nd St. In High Springs and Newberry, a number of homes suffered minor to major damage due to flooding, and several trees fell onto homes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple roads were inundated with floodwaters from Black Creek including Lazy Acres Rd and Scenic Dr. North Fork Black Creek near Middleburg rose to moderate flood stage and crested at 20.13 ft on Aug. 6th. South Fork Black Creek near Penney Farms rose to minor flood stage and crested at 15.54 ft on Aug. 6th. A large oak tree split at the trunk and fell across a lawn in Orange Park. There were two trees that fell and hit|homes and 15 residents reported storm damage to the county. 5.02 inches of rainfall was measured by a CoCoRaHS observer at Keystone Heights 10.0 NE during Debby.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Debby made landfall as a Category 1 storm along the FL Big Bend coast during the early morning of August 5, 2024. Prior to landfall, outer convective bands produced tornadoes across portions of northeast Florida on August 4th. Widespread flooding moved inland with Debby across the Suwannee River Valley and inland Southeast Georgia where flash flooding and moderate to major river flooding occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Surface observations indicate peak wind gusts generally between 50 to 60 mph, with a maximum gust of 52 mph at Brooksville-Tampa Bay Regional Airport at 10:00 AM EST on August 5. Rainfall ranged from 5 to 10 inches, with a maximum total of 8.34 inches near Spring Hill. A peak water level of 3.41 feet above MHHW was measured at the mouth of the Chassahowitzka River at 6:30 AM EST on August 5. Peak water levels estimated elsewhere along coastal Hernando County generally ranged from 2 to 4 feet.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Debby made landfall north of the local area along the Big Bend region of Florida near Steinhatchee around 7 AM EST on August 5th as a Category 1 hurricane with maximum sustained winds of 80 mph and a minimum pressure of 979 mb. Despite Debbys track west of the Florida peninsula, impacts overspread the area from coastal locations spreading inland.|Storm surge affected the immediate coast from Ft. Myers northward through Cedar Key, where water levels peaked over 4 feet above normally dry ground across the upper Nature Coast and the Cedar Key area. Wind gusts of up to 60 to 70 mph affected much of the western Florida coast, with the strongest winds occurring along immediate coastal areas from around Tampa and St. Petersburg northward across Nature Coast locations, producing generally minor damage along with power outages. Torrential rainfall accompanied Debby as the rainbands east of its center moved across the area. Totals as high as 15 to 20 inches were reported, with hardest hit west-central and southwest Florida areas requiring numerous water rescues from flooded vehicles and homes as a result of extensive flash flooding and subsequent river flooding, and at least one official river gauge site established a new record crest. Multiple supercells embedded within outer rain bands east of Debbys center produced at least 3 tornadoes across the area, however, associated damage remained relatively minor. |Debbys overall impacts across the western Florida peninsula resulted in 2 direct fatalities and 3 indirect fatalities, with numerous homes and additional businesses receiving damage from freshwater flash and river flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A long-lived supercell embedded within an outer rainband associated with Tropical Storm Debby tracked north-northwestward across much of interior southwest Florida, including parts of Lee, Charlotte and DeSoto counties, before again exhibiting signs of increased organization as it moved west of Zolfo Springs in Hardee County around 12:08 EST. Continuing north-northwest, and despite a degrading radar presentation, the storm passed west of Bowling Green where a tornado was spotted and reported via a picture submitted by a NWS volunteer, around 12:25 EST. The tornado track continued into Polk County at 12:26 EST, where it would continue for approximately another two-thirds of a mile before dissipating north of County Line Rd. Maximum winds were estimated around 75 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A supercell embedded within an outer rainband associated with Tropical Storm Debby began showing signs of increased organization around 13:40 EST as it moved north-northwest across southern Polk County between Bowling Green and Fort Meade. The storm continued exhibiting signs of increasing organization as it passed west of Fort Meade, before a NWS volunteer relayed video of a tornado associated with the storm around 13:58 EST just north of FL Hwy 640 near Agricola Rd. The volunteer relayed that the tornado continued on the ground for approximately 2 minutes before dissipating over open field after tracking around a mile and a half. No significant damage was reported, with likely only minor tree damage resulting from the tornado. Maximum winds were estimated around 75 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Collier County emergency management reported that in Marco Island an estimated 50 to 70 vehicles were stranded due to flooded roadways and there was flood water intrusion in some low-lying buildings and coastal structures up to 6 inches deep. NWS survey and damage assessments by local officials indicated that flood inundation was mainly 1-2 feet from a mix of rainfall and storm surge.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The center of Debby passed about 140 miles west of Naples as a tropical storm moving north-northwest over the eastern Gulf of Mexico around 8 AM EDT on August 4th. Tropical Storm Debby intensified into a hurricane as it passed southwest of Tampa late August 4th before making landfall in the Florida Big Bend area as a Category 1 hurricane on the morning of August 5th, with maximum sustained winds of 80 mph and lowest central pressure of 979 mb. The outermost edge of Debby's tropical storm force wind field skirted the southwestern Florida Gulf coast on August 3rd and 4th. bringing brief tropical storm force wind gusts to most of the area. The most persistent rain bands moved over western, southern, and central sections of Collier County on August 4th, producing near-tropical storm conditions and rainfall of 4-6 inches. A storm surge of just over 3 feet, in combination with the high rainfall amounts, led to moderate coastal flooding in vulnerable storm surge locations in coastal Collier County during the high tide cycle on August 4th. The heavy rainfall also caused widespread minor to moderate inland flooding across the Naples and Golden Gate areas.||The combination of heavy rainfall and storm surge caused a total of $877,947 in damage in unincorporated sections of Collier County (excluding the cities of Marco Island, Everglades City, and Naples), with 6 properties suffering major damage and 31 with minor damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Surface observations indicate peak wind gusts generally between 50 to 60 mph, with a maximum gust of 58 mph at Cedar Key at 12:48 AM EST on August 5. Rainfall ranged from 6 to 10 inches, with a maximum total of 9.67 inches near the Lower Suwannee National Wildlife Refuge. A direct fatality occurred when a tree fell onto a mobile home and crushed a 13 year old male inside.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several RVs and travel campers were damaged in the Sonrise Palms RV Park in Cocoa when a severe thunderstorm embedded within one of Hurricane Debby's outer rainbands moved across Brevard County. A 99-year-old man was transported to a nearby hospital after the camper he was in was flipped.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The outer rainbands of Hurricane Debby brought periods of thunderstorms to east central Florida. A thunderstorm became briefly severe as it moved northward over Brevard County and over the Sonrise Palms RV Park in Cocoa, where several campers were flipped.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A supercell embedded within an outer rainband associated with Tropical Storm Debby produced a waterspout as it passed west of Treasure Island around 17:44 EST, that was captured on a nearby webcam. The waterspout continued northward, crossing the coast near Madeira Beach in Pinellas County around 17:50 EST, where residents reported minor damage to fencing and a trailer in the Boca Ciega Point community. Radar indicated the circulation weakened shortly thereafter with the tornado estimated to have dissipated around 17:53 EST southwest of Seminole. Maximum winds were estimated around 80 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado produced EF1 tornado damage at 7:40 PM as it touched down |south of State road 238 by snapping the tree trunk of a large hardwood |tree. The tornado proceeded northwestward to a homes along Southwest |85th Path, overturning a travel trailer, knocking down a wooden fence, |and uprooting another hardwood tree. The tornado's last impact was |tearing off the roof of a shed along southwest 85th Path before it |lifted. The tornado was on the ground for about 1 minute and was on |the ground a distance of just under a quarter of a mile. The Tornado |had a maximum width of about 20 yards and had maximum winds up to 93 |mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Debby made landfall as a Category 1 storm along the FL Big Bend coast during the early morning of August 5, 2024. Prior to landfall, outer convective bands produced tornadoes across portions of northeast Florida on August 4th. Widespread flooding moved inland with Debby across the Suwannee River Valley and inland Southeast Georgia where flash flooding and moderate to major river flooding occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Surface observations indicate peak wind gusts generally between 30 to 40 mph, with a maximum gust of 34 mph near Arcadia at 2:10 AM EST on August 5. Rainfall ranged from 3 to 6 inches, with a maximum total of 5.46 inches near Arcadia.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Debby made landfall north of the local area along the Big Bend region of Florida near Steinhatchee around 7 AM EST on August 5th as a Category 1 hurricane with maximum sustained winds of 80 mph and a minimum pressure of 979 mb. Despite Debbys track west of the Florida peninsula, impacts overspread the area from coastal locations spreading inland.|Storm surge affected the immediate coast from Ft. Myers northward through Cedar Key, where water levels peaked over 4 feet above normally dry ground across the upper Nature Coast and the Cedar Key area. Wind gusts of up to 60 to 70 mph affected much of the western Florida coast, with the strongest winds occurring along immediate coastal areas from around Tampa and St. Petersburg northward across Nature Coast locations, producing generally minor damage along with power outages. Torrential rainfall accompanied Debby as the rainbands east of its center moved across the area. Totals as high as 15 to 20 inches were reported, with hardest hit west-central and southwest Florida areas requiring numerous water rescues from flooded vehicles and homes as a result of extensive flash flooding and subsequent river flooding, and at least one official river gauge site established a new record crest. Multiple supercells embedded within outer rain bands east of Debbys center produced at least 3 tornadoes across the area, however, associated damage remained relatively minor. |Debbys overall impacts across the western Florida peninsula resulted in 2 direct fatalities and 3 indirect fatalities, with numerous homes and additional businesses receiving damage from freshwater flash and river flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Surface observations indicate peak wind gusts generally between 30 to 40 mph, with a maximum gust of 43 mph at Sebring Regional Airport at 8:35 PM EST on August 4. Rainfall ranged from 2 to 5 inches, with a maximum total of 4.37 inches near Archbold.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sustained windspeeds generally reached 25 to 35 mph with gusts frequently reaching 40 to 50 mph. Overall, damage to vegetation and infrastructure was limited, with a few reports of tree and powerline damage noted in Lake County. Widespread rainfall amounts of 2 to 4 inches were recorded, with locally higher amounts of 6 to 7 inches in Lake County.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Debby maintained Category 1 strength, with maximum sustained winds of 70 knots, as it brushed portions of east central Florida and made landfall near Steinhatchee, Florida during the morning August 5th. Sustained wind speeds generally reached 25 to 35 mph with gusts frequently reaching 40 to 50 mph. Widespread rainfall amounts of 2 to 4 inches were recorded, with locally higher amounts of 6 to 7 inches in Lake County. Overall, damage to vegetation and infrastructure was limited, with a few reports of tree and powerline damage noted in Lake County. Additionally, a severe thunderstorm within one of Debby's outer rainbands produced damage in Brevard County, where several campers were flipped at an RV park.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were many downed trees and power lines.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Debby made landfall along the Taylor County coast as a Category 1 Hurricane on the morning of Monday August 5th. In addition to storm surge flooding along the FL Big Bend coast, around 12 inches of rainfall lead to widespread flooding in Madison and Taylor counties. In particular, rainfall in Southeast Madison County corresponded to a 0.2% annual chance occurrence or a 500 year flood event. Long duration areal flooding occurred in southeast Madison county for around 3 weeks. Flooding also occurred along portions of the Aucilla, Fenholloway, Steinhatchee and Withlacoochee rivers. Tropical storm force winds also led to power outages in the Florida Big Bend and South-Central Georgia. There were two direct fatalities from trees falling on homes in Dixie County, Florida and Moultrie, Georgia. Two indirect fatalities also occurred in Dixie County due to a traffic accident. The highest water marks measured by a survey team from FDEM were around 3 feet AGL in Horseshoe Beach. The University of Florida estimated that agriculture losses across Florida were between $93.7 million and $263.2 million, including crops, livestock, aquaculture, and animal products.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and power lines were blown down across the county.  A trained spotter estimated winds of 75 mph gusting to 90 mph.  More than 100 homes were damaged from either wind or flooding. Downed trees and power lines resulted in temporary road closures and extended power outages. Power outages lasted up to 3 to 4 days.

In addition to storm surge flooding along the FL Big Bend coast, around 12 inches of rainfall lead to widespread flooding in Madison and Taylor counties. In particular, rainfall in Southeast Madison County corresponded to a 0.2% annual chance occurrence or a 500 year flood event. Long duration areal flooding occurred in southeast Madison county for around 3 weeks. Flooding also occurred along portions of the Aucilla, Fenholloway, Steinhatchee and Withlacoochee rivers. Tropical storm force winds also led to power outages in the Florida Big Bend and South-Central Georgia. There were two direct fatalities from trees falling on homes in Dixie County, Florida and Moultrie, Georgia. Two indirect fatalities also occurred in Dixie County due to a traffic accident. The highest water marks measured by a survey team from FDEM were around 3 feet AGL in Horseshoe Beach. The University of Florida estimated that agriculture losses across Florida were between $93.7 million and $263.2 million, including crops, livestock, aquaculture, and animal products.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency Management reported flooding of |            structures and homes county wide along with |            street and road closers with some vehicles |            stranded.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Debby made landfall as a Category 1 storm along the FL Big Bend coast during the early morning of August 5, 2024. Prior to landfall, outer convective bands produced tornadoes across portions of northeast Florida on August 4th. Widespread flooding moved inland with Debby across the Suwannee River Valley and inland Southeast Georgia where flash flooding and moderate to major river flooding occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The mesonet site at Sebastian Inlet reported a 51 knot wind gust from the west-northwest.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm moving offshore produced a severe wind gust at Sebastian Inlet.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Long duration areal flooding occurred across southeast Madison county due to heavy rainfall of around 12 inches from Hurricane Debby.  The Ragans Family Campground was flooded and forced to close, which resulted in a few hundred campers being evacuated.  Other homes and rural roads were inundated in the area. The flooding was slow to recede in some areas and lasted all the way through August 26th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media relayed pictures of a funnel cloud between Babcock Ranch and Shell Creek.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Afternoon thunderstorms associated with the sea breeze produce a funnel cloud near Shell Creek in Charlotte County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Social media video showing several inches of water covering the entire street with water |past the curb and sidewalks. It was still passable for vehicles in the center of the street. Rainfall estimates in the area were in the 2-3 inch range.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak surface boundary moving across South Florida brought ample instability, lift, and moisture advection to provide conditions prime for afternoon convection on August 15th. Numerous showers and thunderstorms brough the threat for hazards such as heavy downpours, gusty winds, and localized flooding with any slow moving storms.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Naples Police report Gordon Drive, south of Galleon Drive, is impassable due to water on roadway. Rainfall estimates were in the 3-4 inch range, most of this falling in about 2 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak surface boundary moving across South Florida brought ample instability, lift, and moisture advection to provide conditions prime for convection on August 15th. Heavy downpours and localized flooding occurred, with slow-moving storms, as the boundary continued to linger in far southern FL throughout the day on the 16th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An Everglades National Park ranger reported minor saltwater flooding in Everglades City during the high tide cycles. Standing water was less than 1 foot on several roads. Streets affected included Begonia Street, Camellia Street, Buckner Avenue, Kumquat Street, and Starter Avenue. Tide levels at Naples Bay peaked at 1.53 feet MHHW or 4.28 feet MLLW at 1:00 PM August 20th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Higher than normal water levels occurred in late August due to the full moon cycle, or king tides, across the Gulf coast of South Florida. Minor coastal flooding was possible during high tide with the peak height on August 20th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An Everglades National Park ranger reported minor saltwater flooding in Flamingo, on the flood-prone campground adjacent to the water, during the high tide cycles. Standing water was less than one foot on the road at the Flamingo Campground.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Higher than normal water levels occurred in late August due to the full moon cycle, or king tides, across the Gulf coast of South Florida. Minor coastal flooding was possible during high tide with the peak height on August 20th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reports and video from the Orlando-Sanford International Airport tower as well as public and broadcast media show a waterspout developed over Lake Jesup. It remained over the lake and did not move onshore.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm produced a waterspout on Lake Jesup. It did not move onshore.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A passing thunderstorm, with strong microburst wind gusts, cause localized damage at the Homestead General Airport. Numerous small airplanes flipped, as well as bent fencing and light posts. Miami Skydive located at the airport reported 87 mph gusts were measured, at approximately 1:30 pm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled frontal boundary across northern Florida, with steady southwesterly flow, allowed moisture to pool and favored afternoon shower and thunderstorm chances. This allowed for occasional strong to severe thunderstorms with potential for heavy downpours and gusty winds on August 21st.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Media relayed report of a lightning strike that caused a tree to split and fall on multiple vehicles in the Wedgewood community near Palm Harbor.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Morning thunderstorms south of a stalled out frontal boundary over the north-central Florida peninsula produce damaging lightning strikes across Pinellas and Manatee counties.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Media reported building fire caused by a lighting strike to a shopping plaza on Holmes Beach. Time estimated from radar.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Morning thunderstorms south of a stalled out frontal boundary over the north-central Florida peninsula produce damaging lightning strikes across Pinellas and Manatee counties.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public measured 3.31 inches of rainfall in about 90 minutes along the St. Johns River near Federal Point.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak front extended across NE FL from a broad surface low near the NE FL Atlantic coast. A moist and unstable airmass under cooler than normal 500 mb temperatures (-8 degC) triggered strong to pulse severe storms and localized flooding where sea breeze, outflows and boundaries merged near and south of the frontal zone under very weak steering flow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A photo of a funnel cloud over Nassauville was shared via social media. The time and location was based on radar data.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface low meandered offshore of the NE FL coastal along a stalled front. Passing upper-level short wave trough energy, high moisture and slow storm motion produced locally heavy rainfall and pulse strong storms with wet downbursts in resultant storms. Storms impacted coastal areas in the morning, then with diurnal heating shift inland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lingering high moisture with PWATs near 2 inches across NE FL produced locally heavy rainfall in diurnally enhanced afternoon showers and isolated storms.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public pictures relayed via social media showed a brief tornado between Odessa and Trinity. No damage was reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Afternoon thunderstorms associated with the sea breeze produce a brief land spout tornado near Odessa in Pasco County and residential fire due to lightning in Pinellas County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: County dispatch reported a residential fire due to lightning near Seminole causing mostly minor damage.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Afternoon thunderstorms associated with the sea breeze produce a brief land spout tornado near Odessa in Pasco County and residential fire due to lightning in Pinellas County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: County dispatch reported a residential fire due to lightning near Redington Shores causing minor damage.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Afternoon thunderstorms associated with the sea breeze cause a residential fire due to lightning in Pinellas County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: County fire rescue reported a residential structure fire due to a lightning strike near Oldsmar with minor damage.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Afternoon thunderstorms associated with the sea breeze cause a residential fire due to lightning in Pinellas County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 40 year old male visitor drowned after he and his juvenile son were swept out into the Gulf of Mexico by a rip current. Both father and son were taken to the hospital. The son was reportedly in stable condition, but the father did not survive. The drowning occurred at James Lee Park in Destin.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 40 year old male visitor drowned after he and his juvenile son were swept out into the Gulf of Mexico by a rip current. Both father and son were taken to the hospital. The son was reportedly in stable condition, but the father did not survive. The drowning occurred at James Lee Park in Destin.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local broadcast media reported two males sustaining injuries from a lightning strike in the water next to Naples Pier. Time is based on data from the National Lightning Detection Network. Two weeks later, local media reported that one of the men passed away after being in critical condition since the lightning strike.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With afternoon sea breezes and diurnal heating, the development of showers and thunderstorms was fueled across inland and Southwest Florida in the afternoon of August 31st. There were scattered thunderstorms across the local Gulf waters which led to hazards such as gusty winds and lightning along coastal Collier County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media reported knee-deep floodwater in the parking lot a business on Michigan Street in Orlando. Floodwaters entered at least one business. Photos were received of a car stranded along Michigan Street. One video showed cars driving through water that was at least one foot deep.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms produced heavy rainfall and flooded homes and businesses in Orlando.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Street flooding was reported in the Thornton Park neighborhood, with some vehicles partially submerged in water estimated to be waist-deep. Broadcast media reports some homes and an Orange County government office were flooded.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms produced heavy rainfall and flooded homes and businesses in Orlando.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mesonet site near Faver Dykes |            State Park reported 2.53 inches from 5 pm to |            around 7 pm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High moisture and a lingering frontal zone across the area created heavy rainfall rates in diurnally enhanced sea breeze showers and storms. Warm temperatures aloft and slow storm motion aided heavy rainfall amounts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mesonet site indicated heavy rainfall             of 2.58 inches starting just after 5 pm |            until around 725 pm about 3 miles west of Marineland.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High moisture and a lingering frontal zone across the area created heavy rainfall rates in diurnally enhanced sea breeze showers and storms. Warm temperatures aloft and slow storm motion aided heavy rainfall amounts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media reported a partial roof collapse in a duplex near Northeast 10th Avenue and Second Street in Hallandale Beach after heavy rainfall impacted the area. Rainfall amounts of 2 to 3 inches were observed in the area.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As a surface frontal boundary pushed southward through the southeastern United States, winds began to veer south-southeast bringing moist, warm air into South Florida. This supported the development of numerous showers and thunderstorms across the area throughout the day.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local media reported lightning damaging a home in West Park. The lightning struck the pavement outside the home, which then traveled up a metal fence and shot through the ceiling into a bedroom where a 1-year-old baby was sleeping, causing the roof to collapse. No injuries were reported. Time is based on National Lightning Detection Network data which showed several lightning strikes in the immediate area. Damage totals are estimated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As a surface frontal boundary pushed southward through the southeastern United States, winds began to veer south-southeast bringing moist, warm air into South Florida. This supported the development of numerous showers and thunderstorms across the area throughout the day.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A waterspout moved onshore as a landspout on Amelia Island. There was some debris lofted near oceanfront homes, likely from the roofs, as the landspout moved inland. The location is approximated.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A front was stalled across NE FL with a meandering coastal low offshore of the local Atlantic coast. Above normal atmospheric moisture, warm temperatures aloft and slow storm motion produced localized heavy rainfall over a diurnally unstable airmass with waves of gusty showers moving onshore. Wind gusts with the coastal low along the local Atlantic coast increased to 40-50 mph after 8 pm on 9/3 through midnight along the Duval County FL coast.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A funnel cloud was reported via the public on social media over the St Johns River west of Cocoa. It reportedly lasted around 5 minutes.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A funnel cloud was reported over the St Johns River west of Cocoa.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A member of broadcast media reported that lightning struck a home on Marco Island, damaging the attic and leading to a subsequent fire. Flood and urban area Flash flooding caused some structure inundation, cars to be trapped in flood water and widespread road flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 8:40 AM EDT, an NWS employee reported that there was extensive flooding on Philips Highway and Bowden Road. At 10:40 am, broadcast media shared that flood water inundated a home in Englewood and went up to the person's ankles. Widespread street flooding with numerous cars reported as submerged and stranded along roads or ditches. A swift water rescue was conducted to rescue a person stuck in their flooded car with floodwater up to their steering wheel. Multiple roads were closed due to flooding including Sabena Road and Bowden Rd at Richard St and Cagle Rd. Floodwaters went over car wheels or halfway up cars wheel base along Richard St, Bowden Rd, Barnes Rd, Kegler Dr, Revelstroke Dr, Philips Hwy, Reba Ave, Parental Home Rd, Spring Park Rd, Dean Rd, Belfort Rd, Putnam Ave, Vancouver Dr and portions of University Blvd.

At 9 AM EDT, local broadcast media reported street flooding across San Marco. Street flooding and stranded vehicles were reported across Edgewood Ave, Post St, Willow Branch Ave, Beaver St, Kings Rd, Shircliff Way, Goodwin St, Gilmore St, E State St, Clay St, Duval St, Bay St, Hendricks Ave, Palm Ave, Naldo Ave, San Marco Blvd, Thacker Ave, Children's Way, River Rd and Landon Rd.  Floodwaters were halfway up the wheel wells of vehicles. Multiple roads were closed due to flooding including Stockton Road near Beaver Street West and San Marco Blvd at Lasalle St. Multiple photos were shared via Social Media. About 4 to 6 inches of rain fell within the San Marco, Brooklyn and Mixon Town areas.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 8 PM EDT, broadcast media shared a video showing Main St near 8th St was flooded. Floodwaters reached halfway up tires. About 3 to 4 inches of rain fell by this time. At 8:32 pm, emergency management reported that Jefferson Street and the UF Health parking lot was flooded. This is a known flood-prone site due to its proximity to Hogans Creek. About 3 to 4.5 inches of rain had fallen in this area. Videos were later shared showing floodwaters reached up to a woman's waist and above tires on an SUV. Floodwaters began entering homes along Moncrief Creek including along Leonard Cir E and Moncrief Rd. Floodwaters were deep enough that JFRD was unable to evacuate residents from a home along Leonard Cir E. Old St. Augustine Rd and Pritmore Rd were closed due to flooding. Widespread flooding with numerous cars stuck in floodwaters were reported across the San Marco, Downtown Jacksonville, Riverside, Ortega, Avondale, Hogan's Creek, Moncrief park, and Norwood areas.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another wet, unsettled day continued across much of NE FL and coastal SE GA as a surface front draped across north FL lifted slowly northward. Locally, near record high |deep layer moisture with PWAT values 2-2.5 inches were in place with weak steering flow. Waves of morning coastal rainfall expanded inland with diurnal heating.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary front meandered over NE FL with very high atmospheric moisture with PWATs 2.3-2.6 inches. This forcing and moisture combined with passing short wave troughs aloft and weak mesolows created isolated stronger storms with gusty winds and waves of very heavy, locally flooding rainfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported their street was flooded |            and the floodwaters were reaching the first |            step of their neighbors house. They also |            reported that 2.25 inches of rain fell |            within 45 minutes.

This forcing and moisture combined with passing short wave troughs aloft and weak mesolows created isolated stronger storms with gusty winds and waves of very heavy, locally flooding rainfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 24 hour rainfall for South Flagler Beach of 5.77 inches from 9:00am September 8 |            to 9:am September 9 was 5.77 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface front lingered from near St. Augustine to Gainesville with an approaching upper level trough. The upper trough cooled temperatures aloft while high atmospheric moisture continued over the area. Convergent bands of locally heavy rainfall and isolated embedded thunderstorms developed across NE FL as onshore flow increased as high pressure wedged southward from the north and the local pressure gradient increased.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between September 9-13th about 12 inches of rainfall fell across the Penial/Francis area (11.82 was measured at Moates Road on 9/13).  A location at 111 Penial Store Road experienced overflow from lakes in the area. This property was flooded given it's low elevation location downstream of the flooded lakes. Public works identified a crushed 36 culvert in the area of Penial Store Road and the Dinkla Road area. Water from the local lakes caused rainfall to back-up into Mud Lake and it could not drain. Impacts from this flooding event included: at Mud Lake Farm on NW corner of Mud Lake was impacted by water into the Barn/Garage (EM Verified); at 134 Karen Court flood water was in the backyard from Mud Lake and against the home (EM/Red Cross verified); a home at 111 Peniel Store Rd had possible water intrusion and the kitchen roof collapsed (unconfirmed damages, owner not present nor responsive to EM or Red Cross); a home at 116 Green Rd had minor water intrusion into the basement and water came through the floor and walls underground (EM Verified); and a garage had water into it at 263 Davis Lake Rd (EM picture confirmation). All other information and complaints have been for water near homes, next to homes, in yards, or over roads.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Days of heavy rainfall created flooding and drainage issues across portions of Putnam County, including the Mud Lake area. This report is based on survey information from Putnam County Emergency Management.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 2:18 pm, the public shared a photo of  minor street |            flooding at the intersection of N Market St |            and Confederate St. Road was passable. At 3:09 pm, a NWS Employee  reported minor street flooding in Neptune Beach and Atlantic Beach. There was about 2 to 3 inches of standing water on the roads. At 6 pm, Duval county Emergency Management reported flooding along  Dulawan Dr and along Francis Ave between Forsyth Ct and Walter Rd in Neptune Beach.  At 7 pm, Duval EM shared a video of flooding along LaSalle St and San Marco Blvd. Wakes from passing cars was approached businesses.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface front lingered from near St. Augustine to Gainesville with an approaching upper level trough. The upper trough cooled temperatures aloft while high atmospheric moisture continued over the area. Convergent bands of locally heavy rainfall and isolated embedded thunderstorms developed across NE FL as onshore flow increased as high pressure wedged southward from the north and the local pressure gradient increased.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A public weather station in Micanopy measured |            about 4 inches of rain in just under 2 |            hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface front was stalled across north-central FL as high pressure across the mid-Atlantic area shifted southward. Breezy onshore winds and above normal moisture continued to bring waves of heavy coastal showers.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Social media posts contained pictures and videos of street flooding with 6 inches of standing water near Collins Avenue and Northeast 23rd Street in Miami Beach after rounds of showers and thunderstorms moved through the area. Rainfall estimates in the area were 3 to 4 inches in a 3 hour timeframe.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal boundary stalled over Central Florida brought a warm and very moist airmass over South Florida, which combined with ample lift from mid-level troughing to develop widespread slow-moving showers and thunderstorms over the area during the afternoon and evening.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 11:45 am, law enforcement reported a vehicle was stuck due to street flooding in the intersection of Gran Bay Parkway and Corklan Drive. At 1:26 pm, law enforcement reported several vehicles were stuck in flood water at Gran Bay Parkway and Old St. Augustine Road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled front across central FL and strong high pressure over the mid-Atlantic region continued strong onshore flow across the local area. Above normal moisture and passing short wave trough energy from the west to southwest continued to fuel localized heavy flooding rainfall. In addition to the heavy rainfall, gusty winds of 35-45 mph were starting to cause isolated trees to blown on due to saturated grounds, including in Duval county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An emergency manager captured video of a apparent landspout over the Everglades west of Krome Avenue as a thunderstorm moved through the area. The feature moved little and dissipated rather quickly. No damage was observed or reported, thus this is categorized as a strong wind event rather than a tornado.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal boundary stalled over Central Florida brought a warm and very moist airmass over South Florida, which combined with ample lift from mid-level troughing to develop numerous showers and thunderstorms over the area during the afternoon and evening.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ten inches to one foot of standing flood water cover the roads near the intersection of Marathon Parkway and Timuquana Road. There were no stranded vehicles.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media reported that a 16-year-old boy was killed by lightning after being struck while riding a bicycle in the 600 block of SW 67th Avenue in Pembroke Pines during a thunderstorm. The boy was taken to a nearby hospital where he was later pronounced dead. Time is approximate and is based on the timing of a severe thunderstorm that was affecting the area at the time, as well as from National Lightning Detection Network data showing several cloud-to-ground strikes in close proximity.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With a mid-level trough over the Florida Peninsula, and a stationary front positioned over Central Florida, plentiful moisture and instability was in place over South Florida. This resulted in numerous showers and thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening of September 18th across South Florida.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media reported that lightning struck a transformer in the 6800 block of Tyler Street in Hollywood, which knocked down a power line onto a home and started a fire. The fire caused significant damage to the home and property. The residents of the home were able to get out safely. Time is approximate and is based on the timing of a severe thunderstorm that was affecting the area at the time, as well as from National Lightning Detection Network data showing several cloud-to-ground strikes in close proximity.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With a mid-level trough over the Florida Peninsula, and a stationary front positioned over Central Florida, plentiful moisture and instability was in place over South Florida. This resulted in numerous showers and thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening of September 18th across South Florida.
